block.p: Gas Deposits Could Benefit Israelis and Palestinians Foreign energy companies have discovered gas reserves deep below the sea off Israel and the Gaza Strip. Industry experts say Palestinians and Israelis will both profit if they can manage to work together in a high-stakes partnership .

British Fuel-Tax Protests End A blockade of British refineries and storage depots broke up and convoys of oil trucks rumbled past company gates unimpeded for the first time in a week. But Prime Minister Tony Blair warned that most drivers would not immediately see gas back at the pump. A protest leader, Brynle Williams, said he looked for a cut in fuel taxes within 60 days in exchange for the lifting of the siege.

Clinton Going to Vietnam The White House said President Clinton would visit Vietnam soon after the November elections. He would become the first president to step on Vietnamese soil since the end of the war that took 58,000 American lives. The visit would also complete a reconciliation with the Communist government that has unfolded over the last six years.

Inquiry Into Russian Money American officials investigating the movement of billions of dollars through the Bank of New York say much of the money involved tax evasion by Russian businesses, with much of the wrongdoing appearing to have taken place in Russia.

Myanmar Dissidents Released Daw Aung San Suu Ky, left, and eight other leaders of the National League for Democracy party were released after two weeks of unofficial house arrest. They said they would begin political organizing to test the limits of freedom that the military will allow.

Arrest in China Scandal Chinese prosecutors said they had arrested Li Jizhou, a former vice minister of public security. It was the highest-level arrest in the billion-dollar smuggling scandal surrounding the Yuanhua Corporation.

Beijing Acts to Block Asylum Chinese officials provided details surrounding the rape charges filed in Beijing against the founder of the Zhong Gong healing sect. The leader, Zhang Hongbao, sneaked into the American territory of Guam in January and is seeking political asylum in the United States.

Doctors to Evaluate Suharto A Jakarta court ordered an independent medical team to determine former President Suharto's fitness to stand trial for corruption, after he again declined a summons to appear in court, citing ill health.

Uzbek Group on Terror List The Clinton administration added the Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan to a list of foreign terrorist organizations, saying it had strong ties to the Saudi financier Osama bin Laden.

Clinton Questions Handling Of Nuclear Secrets Case President Clinton said he was ''quite troubled'' by the actions of federal officials in the Wen Ho Lee case. He spoke one day after a federal judge in New Mexico harshly criticized the government for tactics that the judge said were unfair and abusive. Justice Department officials said Attorney General Janet Reno, who earlier declined to offer Dr. Lee an apology, would not respond publicly to the president's criticism.

Bush Accepts 3-Debate Plan Gov. George W. Bush withdrew objections to a bipartisan panel's debate schedule, agreeing to three 90-minute prime-time encounters with Vice President Al Gore next month on college campuses in Boston, Winston-Salem, N.C., and St. Louis.
Mr. Bush said reports that raised fresh questions about Mr. Gore's fund-raising efforts suggested that the vice president ''may have crossed a serious line.''

Gore at Musical Fund-Raiser Vice President Al Gore and Senator Joseph I. Lieberman headlined a musical benefit for the Democratic Party in Manhattan that featured many popular music stars. Republicans said the event undercut recent Democratic efforts to curb entertainment industry marketing practices.

Budget Surplus Plan Advances Democrats joined Republicans in the House Ways and Means Committee to pass unanimously a Republican proposal to commit 90 percent of the budget surplus in the next fiscal year to reducing the national debt.

Shootings, Guns and Money Gun violence costs Americans $100 billion a year, according to a new book that seeks to make a comprehensive estimate of the cost of criminal shootings, gun accidents and suicides committed with guns.
Death Penalty Safeguards Several lawmakers vowed to push anew for a law ensuring that defendants in death-penalty cases have competent lawyers and access to DNA testing.

Ban on Blood From Gay Men Government scientists narrowly rejected a proposal to ease a ban on blood donations from gay men, citing a lack of evidence assuring the protection of the nation's blood supply from the virus that causes AIDS.

First Lady Denies Visits Were Tied to Donations Hillary Rodham Clinton acknowledged that supporters of her Senate campaign had spent the night at the White House and at the Camp David presidential retreat, but she denied that the visits were rewards for political contributions. Officials said they were preparing a list of overnight guests, but that it was not ready.
Mrs. Clinton and Representative Rick A. Lazio sought to capitalize on the momentum they both claimed from their Wednesday debate.
Fifth Water Illness Reported Two more people in the region were hospitalized after drinking bottled water, bringing the total number of people affected to five.

Gauging Transit Performance New York City Transit officials say they may replace the method for measuring subway and bus service reliability to make it more understandable and more accurate. Critics say officials are simply seeking to make service appear better without actually improving it.
Bid to Ease Teacher Shortage The New York State Board of Regents will ask the Legislature to let retired teachers return to the classroom at full salary while continuing to receive pension benefits.

CUNY-Trained Teachers Praised The university, the city's largest supplier of teachers, is doing a better job of producing graduates who can pass certification examinations than it did just a few years ago, the State Education Department said.
Columbia and Trump in Talks Columbia University is talking with Donald J. Trump about creating a satellite campus near Lincoln Center at the developer's vast Trump Place project on the Hudson River.

Voucher Findings Questioned A research company said a lead researcher, a Harvard professor, had overstated the gains of academic performance of black students who used vouchers to attend private schools in New York City.

Behind the Tire Recall Current and former employees at the Bridgestone/Firestone plant in Decatur, Ill., suggest that heavy production demands and lax quality control were root causes of the unusually high number of tires produced at the plant that were prone to separation. They also asserted that a prolonged and bitter strike in the mid-1990's had played a big role.

Ford's chairman, William C. Ford Jr., defended his decision to let the company's president, Jacques Nasser, handle public appearances regarding Firestone tire problems on Explorers. And Ford said it would buy back $5 billion of its stock.
Intervention to Help Euro The European Central Bank dipped into foreign reserves to buy $2.16 billion in euros and briefly halt the currency's tailspin against the dollar.
Strong Showing for Oracle Oracle's quarterly results handily surpassed Wall Street estimates, and it announced a 2-for-1 stock split.
The Summer Games Begin The Olympics open today in Sydney, Australia, in what is late winter in the Southern Hemisphere.
The United States beat Norway, 2-0, in the opening match of the Olympic women's soccer tournament.
